entry.title: Combined summary - BIP30 and BIP34 interaction (was Re: [BIP Proposal] Buried Deployments)
entry.summary: The context of the discussion is centered around various issues related to Bitcoin consensus and protocol. One issue discussed is the banning of an invalid block hash, which is not solely a peer-to-peer protocol problem, but rather an implicit "first seen" consensus rule. Eric Voskuil addresses several hash collision scenarios that cause Core to declare blocks invalid based on ordering and argues that such bugs can be fixed without requiring forks or BIPs. Another major topic of discussion is the BIP30 regression hard fork and its impact on Bitcoin consensus. While the hard fork produces deterministic results, it breaks from previous consensus and causes destruction of all unspent outputs in the "replaced" transaction. This decision was made without public discussion, which some find deplorable. The proposed hard fork is seen as a premature optimization that could have catastrophic consequences if a single hash collision occurs. It is recommended that the regression be reverted, and a post-mortem BIP be conducted.The possibility of hash collisions in Bitcoin is also discussed, which could result in a consensus failure or hard fork. The implications of such collisions are explained, including the creation of two different versions of UTXOs and the acceptance of a fork with less PoW by some nodes. The author argues that the Bitcoin protocol is broken due to the recent implementation of code that allows for transaction "replacement" without concern for collision. They suggest that Bitcoin Core and any implementation of the Bitcoin protocol should assume SHA256 collision is impossible and consider introducing an alternative hash algorithm to prevent consensus failure. Overall, the discussions highlight the importance of responsible development behavior in preventing bugs and ensuring proper consensus in the Bitcoin protocol.
